awd_titl_txt: Genomics of Diseases in Wildlife Workshop; June 2-9, 2019; May/June, 2020; Fort Collins, CO
awd_abstract_narration:
Wildlife populations can be drastically affected by the outbreak and transmission of infectious diseases. Examples of this include white nose syndrome which is devastating bat populations in the US, and Chytrid fungus outbreaks that have caused declines in frog populations worldwide.  Some diseases of wildlife, for example, Rabies, Ebola, and West Nike Virus, can cause outbreaks of disease in people, while other infections of wildlife, such as Brucellosis and African Swine Fever, can be fatal to domestic animals and livestock.  Extraordinary new tools greatly improve our ability to detect infection and understand why it sometimes is devastating and sometimes not. While these new technologies make this an exciting time for new discoveries and understanding that will improve wildlife disease management, many researchers would benefit from training in their use. To address this need, we offer hands-on training with real-world data through an intensive workshop "Genomics of Disease in Wildlife" (GDW).  The first two workshops offered in 2017 and 2018 were very successful and provided training for nearly 50 graduate students, post-doctoral fellows, and faculty in Next Generation DNA Sequencing analysis to use in projects about wildlife diseases. Going forward, this project will provide scholarships to 12-14 graduate students or fellows (US citizens) with financial need to attend workshops in 2019 and 2020.  We will preferentially use these funds to enhance diverse or underrepresented minority participation and have been successful in recruiting women and diverse attendees to maximize training impacts. This financial assistance will also facilitate building a cohesive, effective scientific community making breakthroughs in control of infectious wildlife diseases. For example, we have recently published a manuscript helping the scientific community identify critical next challenges, and the GDW workshop alumni are also involved in a listserv to promote communications among a growing number of researchers with interest and expertise in GDW problems.  


Recent technological advances in genomic sciences, and increasingly affordable Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) assay costs, have coalesced to result in powerful tools to monitor, detect, and reconstruct the past, present, and future role of pathogens impacting wildlife populations. Wildlife researchers are thus uniquely positioned to merge ecological, biological, and evolutionary studies with such genomic technologies to exploit unprecedented "Big Data" tools in disease research; however, most researchers lack the training and expertise required to use these computationally intensive methodologies. Previous workshops have consisted of lectures, daily computer labs, and analysis of real-world NGS data.  Previous workshops have provided comprehensive training in the use of genomic tools for investigations of a broad range of interactions between wildlife host species and their pathogens, and provided unique networking opportunities among instructors, guest speakers, and participants. This project will provide support for two additional years of workshops. Funds will be awarded as scholarships for US graduate students and post-doctoral fellows interested in obtaining skills in this emerging area. This award will encourage participation by early career researchers.  Participants will learn modern genomics techniques and generate powerful genomic solutions to ameliorate the local, regional, and global impact of wildlife disease.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Technological advances in genomic sciences, and increasingly affordable Next Generation Sequencing (NGS) costs, have coalesced to result in powerful tools to monitor, detect, and reconstruct the past, present and future role of pathogens impacting wildlife populations. Wildlife researchers are thus uniquely positioned to merge ecological, biological, and evolutionary studies with such genomic technologies to exploit unprecedented ?Big Data? tools in disease research; however, many researchers lack the training and expertise required to use these computationally intensive methodologies that have developed rapidly over the last decade. The goals of the ?Genomics of Disease in Wildlife? workshop series were thus to provide extensive training in applying genomic technologies to studies of wildlife disease to a diverse array of wildlife disease practitioners, researchers, and veterinarians. The funding provided by NSF for the 3rd and 4th workshops (GDW2019, GDW2021) provided scholarships to US graduate students and post-doctoral fellows interested in obtaining skills in this emerging area. The funding permitted us to increase participation of early career scientists and improve inclusivity of participants otherwise lacking the funds to attend.

Intellectual Merit: The workshop successfully achieved the primary goals: 1) An overview of the types of NGS data and their current applications in wildlife disease research; 2) Guidance to implement genomic tools in study design of host and pathogen; 3) Daily computer lab for expert training in the analysis and interpretation of ?real world? NGS data; and 4) Opportunities for interaction and networking with peers, core faculty, and invited experts.  A total of 49 participants were trained from different career stages ranging from graduate students, Ph.D./D.V.M. postdoctoral fellows to early and mid-career professionals. Geographic diversity of the participants ranged from institutions across the USA and included 25% international attendees (2019 only, as covid travel restrictions prevented international attendees in 2021).

These overall objectives provided foundational skills needed to conduct genomic analyses and provide real-world examples to demonstrate how these approaches are applied to wildlife. This was accomplished by incorporating a variety of educational opportunities from computer labs to seminars by leading experts in the field. A typical day of the workshop involved covering an essential component of NGS workflow and implementing it in laboratory practice exercises in succession. Morning sessions were a series of instructional lectures and demonstrations that concisely presented the purpose, justification and implementation of the specific workflow unit. Short ?flash talks? presented by CSU faculty provided exciting examples of ongoing investigations using the method in wildlife disease research. The afternoon sessions were computer- intensive labs in which attendees performed ?hands-on? analyses with real-world genomic data for each workflow topic. Evening plenary lectures from invited faculty concluded each day?s activities.

Teaching tools included exercises of ?real-world? NGS data from a range of pathogens and host species in order to better understand current epidemics. Datasets were organized into files and formatted for demonstration purposes prior to the course to demonstrate key concepts and provide the foundation for computer exercises and teaching tools. Anonymous surveys of the participants post-workshop revealed consistently high scores for scientific content value (GDW2019, GDW2021 average 4.8 of 5).

Broader Impact:  The workshop venue was designed to foster new networks of scientists that would continue to apply genomic tools to advance discovery in wildlife diseases.  The venue at Colorado State University promoted teamwork, positive interactions and discussions among participants through shared experiences within the workshop and all attendees stayed on campus. Post-workshop communications among participants included formation of a Google Group. Post-workshop survey results included high scores for the planning and logistics, IT support, and overall venue experience (average 4.8 of 5).

Participant demographics, professional expertise, and career stage diversity were important to the success of GDW2019 and GDW2021.  The majority of the 49 attendees were women (35) including 3 from under-represented demographics.  Invited guest speakers provided supplementary training, and research examples of genomic impact in understanding wildlife disease outbreaks on a global scale. Attendees were able to meet individually with experts both within the faculty and invited speakers to establish connections, ask specific questions about research ideas and receive valuable suggestions about experimental design and results.

GDW2019 and GDW2021 illustrated the complexity and global prevalence of wildlife disease; enabled collaborative networks from different areas of scientific expertise; underscored the remarkable diversity of host-pathogen interactions in wild and domesticated species; and the important role of genomic technology to find solutions to emerging disease.
